paper_metadata.title: Evaluation of the Saemaul Zero Hunger Communities Project in Tanzania and Bangladesh

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: The project targeted the most vulnerable communities to improve their livelihood and rural development programs in terms of food security, income generation, education, and infrastructure improvement through community-based activities
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: Using qualitative analysis, difference-in-difference estimation, and linear regression on surveys of 1142 respondents

bonus_information.qualitative_evidence_citation: To collect information and data for evaluation, we conducted field research such as in-depth interviews, focus group discussions, and household surveys in the target villages
bonus_information.cost_mentions: US$5 million for Tanzania and US$3.3 million for Bangladesh
bonus_information.cost_evidence_citation: funded by the South Korean government at US$5 million for Tanzania and US$3.3 million for Bangladesh

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: This study aims to evaluate the achievements of the Saemaul Zero Hunger Communities Project (SZHCP) of the World Food Program (WFP) implemented by Good Neighbors International (GNI)
evidence_citations.country_citation: implemented by Good Neighbors International (GNI) in partnership with Tanzanian and Bangladesh local governments
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: The project targeted the most vulnerable communities to improve their livelihood and rural development programs
